channel.title: Tech Made Simple
channel.description: Making software engineering accessible to everyone. Learn complex tech concepts through simple, relatable analogies.

item.title: Webhooks: Think Doorbell Notification
item.description: Webhooks send automatic notifications when events happen. Think of them as a doorbell - rings when someone arrives, you don't check constantly.

item.title: Environment Variables: Think Settings File
item.description: Environment variables store configuration outside your code. Think of them as a settings file - change settings without changing code.

item.title: Regex: Think Find and Replace
item.description: Regular Expressions (Regex) are patterns for finding text. Think of them as super-powered find and replace - search for patterns, not just exact matches.

item.title: Serverless: Think Food Delivery
item.description: Serverless means you don't manage servers. Think of it as food delivery - you don't own a restaurant, just order when hungry.

item.title: TypeScript: Think Spell Checker
item.description: TypeScript adds type checking to JavaScript. Think of it as a spell checker - catches mistakes before you publish.

item.title: GraphQL: Think Custom Menu
item.description: GraphQL is a query language for APIs. Think of it as a custom menu - order exactly what you want, nothing more, nothing less.

item.title: Async/Await: Think Ordering Food
item.description: Async/Await handles operations that take time. Think of it as ordering food - you don't stand frozen waiting, you do other things until it's ready.

item.title: JSON: Think Labeled Boxes
item.description: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a format for storing and exchanging data. Think of it as labeled storage boxes - organized, readable, and easy to transport.

item.title: NPM: Think App Store
item.description: NPM (Node Package Manager) manages JavaScript libraries. Think of it as the App Store for code - download and install pre-built tools instead of building everything yourself.

item.title: Encryption: Think Secret Code
item.description: Encryption scrambles data so only authorized people can read it. Think of it as a secret code - only those with the key can decode the message.
